poem:
Sunshine Veins

The sun inside the cod,  
golden batter crisped like laughter,  
crackles in frying oil.

In a pot,  
earthy vegetables embrace,  
a güveç aroma rises,  
carrying warmth from Cyprus  
to autumn's chill.

Memory served  
in each fragrant bite,  
a sunbeam's taste  
to light the darkened months.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Selin Kiazim’s Turkish-Cypriot recipes for crunchy fried fish and braised vegetables I’m an island baby – my parents were born on the north side of Cyprus and I’ve got sunshine running through my veins – so I spend all of the autumn and winter looking forward to sunnier days. This summer heartache is somewhat soothed, however, by comforting dishes from back home, such as today’s güveç (stew) and fried cod, both of which are hearty". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Selin Kiazim’s Turkish-Cypriot recipes for crunchy fried fish and braised vegetables I’m an island baby – my parents were born on the north side of Cyprus and I’ve got sunshine running through my veins – so I spend all of the autumn and winter looking forward to sunnier days. This summer heartache is somewhat soothed, however, by comforting dishes from back home, such as today’s güveç (stew) and fried cod, both of which are hearty
